content:
I reviewed [redacted name] today following completion of fractionated stereotactic radiotherapy to his thyrotroph pituitary adenoma. He completed treatment on March 15th 2024, receiving 50.4Gy in 28 fractions. The treatment was generally well-tolerated with only mild fatigue and occasional headaches which resolved with simple analgesia.?
?
His initial presentation in September 2023 was with headaches and visual disturbance, leading to the identification of a 2.8cm pituitary macroadenoma. Immunohistochemistry from the surgical specimen confirmed a thyrotroph adenoma (SF1 negative, PIT1 positive). He underwent partial trans-sphenoidal resection on October 12th 2023, achieving good decompression of the optic chiasm but with residual tumor along the right cavernous sinus measuring 1.5cm.?
?
I am pleased to report that his symptoms have significantly improved since completing radiotherapy. His headaches have completely resolved and his visual fields have normalized according to the ophthalmology review on April 1st 2024. The latest MRI from April 10th shows stable appearance of the residual disease with no evidence of progression.?
?
Endocrine function remains stable on replacement with levothyroxine 100mcg daily. His most recent thyroid function tests show TSH 1.2 mU/L (0.4-4.0) and free T4 16 pmol/L (12-22). Cortisol axis remains preserved with normal short synacthen test results.?
?
He continues to work full-time as an accountant and maintains good exercise tolerance with regular swimming. On examination today, his visual fields are full to confrontation and cranial nerves are intact.?
?
The plan is to continue current hormone replacement and arrange follow-up MRI pituitary in 3 months. We will review him in the combined pituitary clinic with endocrinology in July 2024. I have provided him with contact details for the specialist nurse should he develop any concerning symptoms in the interim.

cancer_timeline.value: 2.8cm pituitary macroadenoma identified on initial presentation
Partial trans-sphenoidal resection with residual tumor 1.5cm along right cavernous sinus
Completed fractionated stereotactic radiotherapy 50.4Gy in 28 fractions
MRI shows stable appearance of residual disease with no progression

patient_facts.value: Previous symptoms of headaches and visual disturbance now resolved
Normal visual fields on ophthalmology review
TSH 1.2 mU/L and free T4 16 pmol/L on levothyroxine replacement
Normal cortisol axis with normal short synacthen test
Working full-time as accountant with regular swimming exercise
Visual fields full to confrontation and cranial nerves intact

status_updates.value: Thyrotroph pituitary adenoma treated with surgery and radiotherapy. Good clinical response with stable residual disease and normalized visual fields
Complete resolution of headaches and normalization of visual fields following radiotherapy
Mild fatigue and occasional headaches during radiotherapy, resolved with simple analgesia
Combined pituitary clinic review with endocrinology in July 2024
